items.message: River levels are stable or falling. Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Saturday is forecast to be mostly dry with the odd isolated shower. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels today, 17th January 2026, may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels at Torksey Gauge will remain high until the 19/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on 18/01/26 or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock Gauge and may rise further tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation & liaising with professional partners. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water & avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
River levels are continuing to rise on the River Thames. Therefore flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, especially in the Abingdon, Culham and Sutton Courtenay areas. Isolated showers are expected today (17/01/26), with a band of rain expected tomorrow morning. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the afternoon of 17 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 17 January 2026. items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels expected to cause flooding over the next three days. Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next several days, and therefore river levels will remain high. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Refer to local authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 4PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible today, 17 January 2026. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.message:
This is a Flood Alert Update. Flooding is possible on 17 January 2026. River levels remain high at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and the recent rainfall. There is still a possibility of flooding for tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch, with low lying land and roads near rivers expected to be most affected.

Although some isolated showers remain, there is no significant or heavy rain forecast for today or tomorrow. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible on 17 January 2026.  This information is correct as of 15:30 on Saturday 17 January. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 28 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney and Earith causeways. Due to the uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. Flooding is possible today as result of Thursday's heavy rainfall. The weather forecast is improving, and we expect levels to start returning to normal soon.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The Combe Haven is still higher than normal in Bulverhythe, but now falling following Thursday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue, with water still affecting gardens, fields, and roads. In Crowhurst, river levels have already fallen nearer to normal and only minimal residual flood impacts are expected. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday to Tuesday, which should not increase flood risk significantly. River levels should continue to fall in all communities. Minor flood impacts could remain in Bulverhythe until Sunday afternoon. River levels in Bulverhythe are unlikely to return nearer to normal until the middle of next week. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the morning of 17 January 2026 . 
Areas most at risk are locations near the River Yeo, Huish Episcopi Main Drain, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Muchelney and Thorney.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3 m, but this is not expected.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
Spillways have stopped running and we have opened the Parrett Relief Channel. Pumping will start as soon as river levels allow.
The weather is unsettled and isolated showers are possible. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Saturday is forecast to be mostly dry with the odd isolated shower. We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens. items.message: Heavy rain has fallen through Thursday 15 January. River levels remain high leading to flooding of low lying land and roads particularly on and around Penhurst and Water Lane. There is no significant rainfall in the forecast and river levels are falling. We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and work with emergency services and local authorities.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

The Western Rother is still high, but now falling following Thursday's rain. Water will still be close to properties, and affecting gardens, fields, and roads. At Lodsbridge near Selham the river is still high, but has fallen significantly from its peak. At Lodsbridge flood impacts will continue to affect fields, gardens, and roads. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen nearer to normal and only minimal residual flood impacts are expected. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday to Tuesday, which should not increase flood risk significantly. River levels should continue to fall in all communities. Minor flood impacts could remain in Fittleworth until Sunday afternoon. River levels in Fittleworth are unlikely to return nearer to normal until the middle of next week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider keeping flood protection products in place, in Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood. This message will be updated by 13:00 18/01/2026.

The River Ouse is still higher than normal in Barcombe, but now falling following Thursday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue, with water still affecting gardens, fields, and roads. Including Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and Barcombe Mills Road. Near Ardingly, Lindfield, and Scaynes Hill, river levels have already fallen nearer to normal and only minimal residual flood impacts are expected. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday to Tuesday, which should not increase flood risk significantly. River levels should continue to fall in all communities. Minor flood impacts could remain in Barcombe until Sunday. River levels in Barcombe should return nearer to normal by Sunday afternoon. We are operating structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood, including Barcombe Mills Road. This message will be updated by 13:00 18/01/2026.

This is a Flood Alert Update. Flooding is possible on 17 January 2026. River levels continue to be high, but are beginning to level off. Flooding is still possible in locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.

Although some isolated showers remain, there is no significant or heavy rain forecast for today or tomorrow.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. Groundwater levels are falling but further rainfall in the coming days may lead to levels rising once more. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.  
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Little Venice Country Park and Marina
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Medway, River Teise, River Beult

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high overnight on Saturday 17 January. Flooding is possible of low lying land and roads close to the River Great Stour. There is no significant rainfall in the forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message:
Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the morning of 17 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell
items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 17 January 2026. Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell, including Dogsmouth Brook. The weather forecast is improving, and we expect levels to start returning to normal soon. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday 18 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
